description.summary: The duplicate or double of a living person, appearing as an exact replica. May be seen by the person themselves or by others, often considered an omen of death or misfortune in traditional folklore.
description.full: A doppelgänger (German for 'double-goer' or 'double-walker') is the apparitional double or duplicate of a living person. The phenomenon manifests in several forms: individuals seeing their own double (autoscopy), others witnessing someone in two places simultaneously (bilocation), or crisis apparitions where doubles appear at moments of danger or death. Historically considered an omen of death or bad luck, the doppelgänger phenomenon spans cultures worldwide and has been documented throughout history, from ancient folklore to modern neurological case studies. Famous historical cases include Goethe meeting himself on a road, Abraham Lincoln's double reflection, and the extensively documented case of teacher Emilie Sagée (1845-46). Modern science recognizes some doppelgänger experiences as neurological conditions (autoscopy, heautoscopy) while others remain unexplained, bridging paranormal, psychological, and potentially quantum phenomena.

etymology.meaning: Double-goer or double-walker - one who walks alongside
etymology.first_use: 1796, introduced by German writer Jean Paul Richter in novel 'Siebenkäs'

related_phenomena.name: Bilocation
related_phenomena.description: Being in two places simultaneously, often reported in religious contexts

related_phenomena.name: Astral Projection
related_phenomena.description: Out-of-body experience where consciousness travels separately

related_phenomena.name: Crisis Apparition
related_phenomena.description: Apparition appearing at moment of death or danger

related_phenomena.name: Autoscopy
related_phenomena.description: Neurological condition of seeing one's own body from external perspective

manifestation_types.description: Individual sees their own double, typically from external perspective
manifestation_types.context: Often neurological, during altered states, or spontaneous

manifestation_types.description: Others see person in two different locations simultaneously
manifestation_types.context: Person usually unaware their double is being seen

manifestation_types.description: Double appears to loved ones at moment of danger or death
manifestation_types.context: Often occurs during accidents, illness, or trauma

manifestation_types.description: Double appears before the actual person arrives (Vardøger)
manifestation_types.context: Double performs actions the person will do moments later

physical.appearance: Exact duplicate of the living person in every detail
physical.visibility: Typically visible only to select witnesses
physical.solidity: Ranges from fully solid to translucent or shadowy
physical.behavior: May mirror original person's actions or act independently

characteristics_features.description: Perfect physical duplicate including clothing and mannerisms
Original person exists elsewhere while double appears
Double rarely speaks or interacts meaningfully
Witnesses experience unease, dread, or uncanny valley sensation
Folklore links seeing one's double to impending death

behavior.awareness: Double rarely shows awareness of observers
behavior.location_pattern: Can appear anywhere, no geographic limitation
behavior.temporal_pattern: No consistent time pattern, often during emotionally significant moments

range.description: Global phenomenon reported across all cultures and time periods. No geographic concentration; appears universally in human experience.

cultural_variants.name: Fetch (Irish)
cultural_variants.description: Death omen double, seeing it means death within a year

cultural_variants.name: Vardøger (Norse)
cultural_variants.description: Premonitory double that arrives before the person, performs their future actions
cultural_variants.cultural_significance: Common in Norwegian and Icelandic folklore

cultural_variants.name: Ka (Egyptian)
cultural_variants.description: Spiritual double born with every person, part of soul complex
cultural_variants.cultural_significance: Integral to Egyptian theology and afterlife beliefs

cultural_variants.name: Etiäinen (Finnish)
cultural_variants.description: Spirit predecessor, ghostly precursor of living person
cultural_variants.cultural_significance: Part of Finnish folk belief system

first_recorded.source: Ancient Egyptian Ka concept, Greek mythology, Norse sagas

temporal.historical_continuity: Documented continuously from ancient times through present day
temporal.modern_frequency: Still reported regularly, though often explained neurologically

origins.cultural_roots: Universal human experience across cultures. Ancient Egyptians believed in the Ka (spiritual double), Greeks had stories of doubles, Norse mythology included Vardøger, Celtic cultures had the Fetch.
origins.earliest_accounts: Ancient Egyptian texts (Ka concept), Greek mythology (eidolon), ancient Germanic folklore
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to death omens, soul beliefs, spiritual doubles, and concepts of divided self across world cultures.

timeline.significance: Egyptian theology includes Ka as spiritual double of every person
Greeks described spirit images and doubles in mythology and philosophy
Johann Wolfgang von Goethe reports meeting his own double on horseback
Jean Paul Richter introduces word in novel 'Siebenkäs'
French teacher's double repeatedly witnessed by students and staff; extensively documented
timeline.source: Dale Owen's 'Footfalls on the Boundary of Another World' (1860)

timeline.significance: Lincoln sees double reflection in mirror, interprets as death omen
Queen's double seen on bed shortly before her death
Medical science identifies autoscopy and heautoscopy as neurological phenomena
Related neurological condition identified where patients believe loved ones replaced by doubles
timeline.source: Capgras, J. & Reboul-Lachaux, J. psychiatric research

history.modern_era: Modern understanding combines folklore, neurology, and psychology. Autoscopic phenomena are recognized as neurological conditions affecting brain's body schema, while other cases remain unexplained. The phenomenon continues to be reported and maintains cultural significance in literature, film, and popular culture.

notable.name: Emilie Sagée Double
notable.description: French teacher Emilie Sagée's double was repeatedly seen by students and staff over 18 months. Witnesses reported seeing her double standing beside her while she wrote on the blackboard, sitting in a chair while she stood across the room, and performing actions she was simultaneously doing elsewhere. In one notable incident, 13 students watched as Sagée's double appeared in her empty chair while she was visible working in the garden outside. The double sometimes moved, sometimes remained motionless. Sagée herself never saw her double and was unaware of its appearances. Despite being an excellent teacher, she was dismissed due to parents' concerns.

credibility.notes: Most extensively documented historical doppelgänger case. Robert Dale Owen investigated and published detailed account in 1860.

sources: Dale Owen, R. (1860). Footfalls on the Boundary of Another World
Flammarion, C. (1923). Death and Its Mystery

notable.name: Goethe's Self-Encounter
notable.description: German writer Johann Wolfgang von Goethe reported encountering his exact double riding toward him on horseback, wearing clothes he didn't yet own (gray suit with gold trim). Eight years later, Goethe found himself riding the same road in the opposite direction, wearing the exact clothes he had seen on his double. He interpreted this as a premonitory vision of his future self.

factors: But witness is credible historical figure
credibility.notes: Classic literary account that popularized doppelgänger concept in European culture.

sources: Goethe, J.W. (1811-1833). Dichtung und Wahrheit (Poetry and Truth)

notable.name: Lincoln's Double Reflection
notable.description: On the evening of his election to presidency, Abraham Lincoln saw his reflection in a mirror appear doubled - one face healthy and vivid, the other pale and ghostly. He saw this twice. Lincoln's wife Mary interpreted it as an omen: he would serve his first term in good health but would not survive his second term. Lincoln was indeed assassinated during his second term in 1865.
evidence: Lincoln's personal accounts to family and colleagues

credibility.notes: Well-documented historical account, though interpretation as death omen may be retrospective.

sources: Keckley, E. (1868). Behind the Scenes: Thirty Years a Slave and Four Years in the White House
Sandburg, C. (1926). Abraham Lincoln: The Prairie Years

historical_accounts.name: Emilie Sagée Documentation
historical_accounts.description: Extensive witness testimony from 40+ students and staff
historical_accounts.analysis: Most thoroughly documented historical case; witnesses consistent and credible

neurological.name: Autoscopy cases
neurological.description: Neurological phenomenon where patients see their own body from external perspective
neurological.analysis: fMRI and neurology studies identify temporoparietal junction involvement
neurological.source: Neurology journals, Blanke et al. research

neurological.name: Heautoscopy cases
neurological.description: Neurological condition involving seeing one's double with feeling of doubled self
neurological.analysis: Related to autoscopy but involves stronger identification with the double

psychological.name: Capgras Delusion
psychological.description: Patients believe loved ones have been replaced by identical doubles
psychological.analysis: Related to impaired face recognition and emotional response disconnect

folklore.name: Irish Fetch traditions
folklore.description: Extensive Celtic folklore about death omen doubles

paranormal.name: Astral Double
paranormal.description: The double is the person's astral body or spirit temporarily separating from physical body

paranormal.name: Death Omen
paranormal.description: Traditional belief that seeing one's double is a supernatural warning of impending death
evidence_cited: Historical accounts where death followed sighting

paranormal.name: Time Anomaly
paranormal.description: Double represents temporal displacement - seeing future or past self

scientific.name: Autoscopy (Neurological)
scientific.description: Brain dysfunction in temporoparietal junction creates illusion of seeing one's own body externally

scientific.name: Heautoscopy
scientific.description: More complex neurological phenomenon involving doubled sense of self and location

scientific.name: Dissociative States
scientific.description: Psychological dissociation creates perception of separated self

psychological.name: Hallucination
psychological.description: Visual and sensory hallucinations create perception of duplicate person

psychological.name: Projection and Identification
psychological.description: Psychological projection of self-image externalized through stress or trauma

psychological.name: Mistaken Identity
psychological.description: Witnesses mistake similar-looking person for the individual

quantum.name: Parallel Universe Glimpse
quantum.description: Brief visual access to parallel timeline where duplicate exists
quantum.notes: Highly speculative with no empirical support

folklore.beliefs: Across cultures, seeing one's double is traditionally considered a death omen or warning. Some traditions view the double as the soul temporarily separating from body. Others see it as supernatural messenger or premonition.

contexts: Catholic bilocation saints (Padre Pio, St. Anthony, St. Alphonsus Liguori)
Egyptian Ka - spiritual double in afterlife theology
religious.significance: Religious traditions often view bilocation as miraculous gift of holy individuals, distinct from ominous folkloric doppelgängers.

literature: "The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde" by Robert Louis Stevenson (1886)
"The Picture of Dorian Gray" by Oscar Wilde (1890)

researchers.name: Dr. Olaf Blanke
researchers.contribution: Leading neurological research on autoscopy and out-of-body experiences

researchers.name: Dr. Peter Brugger
researchers.contribution: Neurological and psychological research on autoscopic phenomena

researchers.name: Robert Dale Owen
researchers.contribution: Documented and investigated Emilie Sagée case and other historical accounts

researchers.name: Camille Flammarion
researchers.contribution: Collected and analyzed historical doppelgänger accounts

organizations.name: Society for Psychical Research
organizations.focus: Historical investigation of apparitions and doubles

organizations.name: Laboratory of Cognitive Neuroscience (EPFL)
organizations.focus: Scientific research on bodily self-consciousness and autoscopy

research.ongoing_studies: Current research focuses on neurological basis of autoscopic phenomena using fMRI and electrical brain stimulation, psychological aspects of dissociation and identity, and documentation of contemporary cases.

sources.title: Footfalls on the Boundary of Another World
Out-of-body experience and autoscopy of neurological origin
